41.words: I think seeing it as a set of tools, and I had this experience a few times. There's a subject that I hated in undergrad, which was statistics because it really felt like just a set of tools that I had to apply. I was like, "Why does it matter at all?" But then I started to find the beauty in statistics, even though beforehand I was shown what type of things it could come from, and so I think I'm more of a meta level. There is this idea of us having or us as humanity having built this concept from practice. So algebra and geometry came from philosophers and mathematicians 2,000 years ago looking at it on this end, on the size of not a computer, but measuring things and realizing that these things could be represented in an abstract manner, in a way that was allowing us to do much more than what we could do with our physical life, and also created this system of very coherent knowledge that it is very relaxing to me because of how much we can... I'm kind going in all the directions, but there is really this kind of meta idea of us having an abstraction of reality that is extremely simple and elegant in a way, and that is representing a really hard complexity with a few axioms. The specificity of having that, just a set of axioms that this whole universe of rule, and objects that interact with one another in a way that is actually relevant back to our sentient life, which is something that I found quite incredible and how far math led us in terms of physics as emerging from us being capable of having more and more sophisticated representation of the complexity of human life and nature. Nature much more. I did my PhD in trying to model human behaviors, and we are really at the infancy of such fields. So that was the one, I think, and also, there's this feeling of not having... We know that something is true, which is very frustrating, I think, for when we with actually human because we don't know that much what is true and what is not true, but it's a field where you have axioms, and you can prove things. There's something I found really relaxing to know that I know when something is true, even though this can have limits, of course. Now, I'm limited here, and that are cultural, but when they are, this feeling of knowing that something is true is something I find fascinating.

98.words: Okay, I'm going to choose this labyrinthine picture because I think this is more of a systemic kind of issue. I noticed when I was doing my bachelors and masters in engineering, none of my courses really went into research ethics or ethics of engineering or tried to kind of contextualize technology development within society or a larger system. I feel like that was kind of lacking in my education, before my PhD. I've now come to seek it out more intentionally. I don't know if that's more of a lack of ethics of the people in charge of my education. Maybe it's more of a lack of forethought or something, but yeah, I think that was, and so I chose this labyrinth because I think creating technology is like you're kind of navigating a labyrinth of the real world and different people that are going to be using it, and the different impacts that it's going to have out in the real world. 99.words: I'm going to play this one and it's going to be a bridge. I picked this one. I didn't really explain the other one I picked it because it was beauty and at the same time being lost [inaudible], but for this one, I would say for me a moment which made me the doubt that the people in charge of my education was I think when I was moving forward with my PhD, and I picked this one because it's chaotic, and ugly, and everybody looks kind of fucked up, and hallucinating, and yelling, and I don't know. I think when I started research I was like, "Oh, everybody's there for the science, and that's what people care about, and they're there for making discovery." And then I just realized how far it was from the truth when you actually see people in real life, and the fact that they have ego, and there's going to be cases of harassment, plagiarism, data stealing, all kind of ego quarrel, and like, "Oh, I hate this person because his science is not sound. Oh, yeah. I wanted to be in this position and he took this position, and therefore blah, blah, blah, and therefore, all the students are shit." And it was like the aspect of dirty politics out of it was absolutely disgusting for me, including by the people that I was working for directly that were leading me. So that was not great. I don't know how I managed to stay here because I'm still doing research. I think I picked it because I don't think it's that different in a lot of other fields. My brother works for a private company and he also hates his manager, and there is also like, "Oh, this person tried to start this project, and this person is very abusive to the team," and stuff like that. So I just think it's like that everywhere, but at least I knew that when I would be done with my PhD, I could do a lot of... The level of freedom I would get to would be massive. I could choose which project I work with, and if I don't want to work with that person, well I would not work with that person because now I'm my own researcher and I can decide if I make a project with this person or not, but that was a tough moment.

People publish very important papers and book when they're actually young, and they're starting their career and they have to get a job, and they are still working a lot, and then because people still see the star of what they published 20 years ago, they still think, "Oh, they are up-to-date with whatever is going on," but actually, a lot of people don't do that anymore. They publish their thing, and now it's done, and they have no idea what's going on.
